Name: DDD
Description: DDD is a chlorophenylethane that is 2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane substituted by two chloro groups at position 1. It is a metabolite of the organochlorine insecticide, DDT. It has a role as a xenobiotic metabolite. It is an organochlorine insecticide, a member of monochlorobenzenes and a chlorophenylethane.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Villeneuve JP, Holm E; Chemosphere 13: 1133-8 (1984) (2) Bacci E et al; Chemosphere 17: 693-702 (1988) (3) Tremolada P et al; Chemosphere 27: 2235-52 (1993) (4) Barriada-Pereira M et al; Chemosphere 58: 1571-1578 (2005)
plant_concentrations.Value: DDD was detected in Swedish lichens (Cladonia alpestris), near Lake Rogen, at concns of 0.02 to 0.49 parts per trillion(1). DDD was detected in mango leaves collected from 5 countries in western Africa at concns of 0.4-58 ng/g(2). DDD was detected in mango leaves collected in various locations of Africa at concns of 0.1-570 ng/g(3). DDD was detected in dry vegetation samples of five plant species taken from Galicia in northwest Spain. DDD levels ranged from below detection limit to 0.025 mg/kg in Cytisus striatus, to 0.067 mg/kg in Avena sativa, to 0.029 mg/kg in Vicia sativa, to 0.024 mg/kg in Solanum nigra, and to 0.030 mg/kg in Chenopodium vulgare(4).

plant_concentrations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 642
plant_concentrations.Value: In aquatic vascular plants in Lake Paijanne, Finland: 0.5 ug/kg dry weight (1972-1973).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Wiemeyer SN et al; Estuaries 3: 155-67 (1980) (2) Ohlendorf HM et al; Pest Monit J 14: 125-35 (1981) (3) Barbehenn KR, Reichel WL; J Toxicol Environ Health 8: 325-30 (1981) (4) Causey K et al; J Agric Food Chem 20: 1205-9 (1972) (5) McEwen LC et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 3: 367-76 (1984) (6) Reichel WL et al; Environ Monit Assess 4: 395-403 (1984) (7) Wiemeyer SN et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 13: 529-49 (1984) (8) Kumar KS et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 48: 538-551 (2005)
animal_concentrations.Value: DDD was detected in 33 out of 33 ospreys from 6 states in the eastern US (1964-73) at the following concns: brains, <0.16-18 ppm (wet wt); carcass, 0.06-18 ppm (wet wt)(1). DDD was identified, not quantified, in 69 out of 69 herons found dead or moribund from 1966-78(2). The avg concn of DDD in bald eagles in the US was reported as 0.44 ppm wet wt(3). DDD was detected in white-tailed deer and rabbits in Alabama from 1968-69 at an avg concn of 0.62 ppm and 0.32 ppm, respectively(4). DDD was detected in 24 of 147 eggs of black-crowned night herons in Wyoming and Colorado at an avg concn of 0.26 ppm(5). DDD was detected in 202 of 293 dead or moribund US Bald eagles at a median concn of 10.7 ppm(6). DDD was identified, not quantified, in 79 out of 89 US Bald eagles from 1969-1979(7). DDD was detected in the liver and egg of great cormorants (Phalacrocorax carbo) and their source of food, gizzard shad, from samples taken along in and around Tokyo, Japan between 1998 and 2000(8). The mean concn of DDD in cormorant liver (n = 10) was 290 ng/g lipid with a range of 62-930 ng/g lipid. In coromorant egg (n = 10) the mean concn was 45 ng/g lipid with a range of 15-20 ng/g lipid. In gizzard shad, the mean concn was 580 ng/g lipid with a range of 150-1000 ng/g lipid(8).

animal_concentrations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 642
animal_concentrations.Value: Mean residues in eggs of American crocodile in Everglades National Park, 0.11 ppm wet weight (1972), 0.04 ppm wet weight (1977). Residues in the seal, Baltic Sea, blubber, 10 mg/g.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Zaroogian GE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 4: 3-12 (1985) (2) Garten CT Jr, Trabalka JR; Environ Sci Technol 17: 590-5 (1983) (3) Veith GD et al; J Fish Res Board Can 36: 1040-48 (1979) (4) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994) (5) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY, 1: 642 (2001)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: BCF values were measured as 52,500 in Pimephales promelas (fathead minnow)(1) and 83,200 in fish(2). The mean BCF of fathead minnows exposed to DDD in a flow-through aquarium was reported as 51,000(3). According to a classification scheme(4), these BCF values suggest that bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high(SRC). BCF values were measured as 9,120 in Mytilus edulis (mussel) and 47,900 in Crassostrea virginica (oyster)(1). Bioconcentration factors for DDD in an aquatic model ecosystem were reported as 6210 in algae; 4460 in snail (Cipaugopaludina japonica); 2710 in carp (Cyprinus carpio); 9,120 in pelecypod (Mytilus adulis) at a concn of 0.05-2.18 ug/1 and 50 hr exposure(5).

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: Hayes, W. J., Jr. Toxicology of Pesticides Baltimore: Williams & Wilkins, 1975., p. 490
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: From 1949 through 1957 total of 54,800 kg of DDD /to control gnat population/ was put directly into /clear/ lake. ... Injury to grebes ... was attributed to chemical. Analysis of wide variety of samples ... DDD was present ... Concn incr in order: plankton-small fish-big fish and grebes.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Vind HP et al; Biodeterioration of Navy Insecticides in the Ocean p 14 NTIS AD-77310 (1973) (2) Tabak HH et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 53: 1503-18 (1981) (3) Eichelberger JW, Litchtenberg JJ; Environ Sci Technol 5: 541-4 (1971) (4) Bartha R et al; Appl Microbiol 15: 67-75 (1967)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: No degradation of DDD was observed after 12 months in aerobic ocean sediments(1). DDD was not degraded in static screening tests using settled domestic wastewater inoculum with yeast extract, with 3 additional subcultures every 7 days(2). No degradation of DDD was observed after 8 weeks exposure of DDD in lab tests to raw water from a stream which received domestic and industrial wastes and farm runoff(3). DDD is very stable in Nixon sandy-loam where it had no effect on carbon dioxide production and nitrification rates(4).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for DDT, DDE, and DDD. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2002) (2) Vind HP et al; Biodeterioration of Navy Insecticides in the Ocean p 14 NTIS AD-77310 (1973) (3) Johnson B; Setting Revised Specific Numerical Values. April, 1991. EH 91-6. Calif Dept Food Agric, Div Pest Manag, Environ Prot Worker Saf, Environ. Monit Pest Manag Branch, Environmental Hazards Assessment Program. 17 pp. (1991)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: DDD was degraded to DDMU (1-chloro-2,2-bis[p-chlorophenyl]ethylene) under methanogenic or sulfidogenic conditions. DDMU degrades further under anaerobic conditions to 2,2-bis(chlorophenyl)acetonitrile (DDNU) and other subsequent degradation species, such as 2,2-bis(chlorophenyl)ethanol (DDOH) and 2,2-bis(chlorophenyl)acetic acid (DDA)(1). No degradation of DDD was observed after 12 months in anaerobic ocean sediments(2). The half-life of DDD in anaerobic soil microcosms was reported as 160 days(3).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Gelschleichter CA et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 48: 474-483 (2005) (2) Takazawa Y et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 74: 652-659 (2005) (3) Ang CW et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 75: 170-174 (2005) (4) Yang Y et al; Chemosphere 62: 381-9 (2006)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: DDD was detected in the liver, muscle, and blood serum of bonnethead sharks (Sphyrna tiburo) taken from four Florida estuaries. In Apalachicola Bay, DDD was detected at concns of 23.80 ng/g in liver (n = 18), 6.96 ng/g (n = 20) in muscle, and 9.60 ng/mL in serum (n = 5). In Charlotte Harbor, the mean concn in liver (n = 10) was 2.48 ng/g. In Florida Bay, the mean concn was 2.20 in liver (n = 16), 11.00 ng/g in muscle (n = 15), and 7.64 ng/mL in serum (n = 31). In Tampa Bay, mean concn of DDD was 11.67 ng/g in liver (n = 18), 5.55 ng/g in muscle (n = 15), and 9.21 ng/mL in serum (n = 29)(1). DDD was not detected in the muscle tissues of rainbow trout, Japanese dace, and Kokanee from Lake Mashu, Japan during a monitoring study conducted in August 2002 and September 2003. However, DDT and DDE were detected in muscle tissue at concns of 0.27 to 4.24 ng/g wet weight. Lake Mashu is located in a remote area with no major sources of pollutant emissions and is fed through the precipitation and permeation of groundwater through cracks(2). During a monitoring study conducted in Malaysia, DDD was detected in mussels (Anadara granosa) and cockles (Perna viridis) taken from four sampling sites. The mean concns of DDD in cockles from Kuala Juru and Juala Selangor were 10.9 ng/g wet weight and 14.9 ng/g wet weight, respectively. In mussels, the mean concns of DDD were 15.1 ng/g wet weight and 9.6 ng/g wet weight in Sebatu and Sungai Danga, respectively(3). DDD was detected in mollusks (Simonovacula constricta) at 9.8 ng/g wet weight, taken from a sampling site in the Yangtze River, China in July 2002. This was the only detection site for DDD among the 7 sampling sites in the study(4).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Eisenberg M, Topping J; J Environ Sci Health B20: 729-42 (1985) (2) Burggraaf F et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 57: 111-17 (1996) (3) Brevik EM et al; Chemosphere 33: 2189-2200 (1996) (4) Berg V et al; Mar Environ Res 44: 35-48 (1997) (5) Bakre PP et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 45: 394-98 (1990) (6) Galceran MT, Santos FJ; Chemosphere 27: 1183-1200 (1993) (7) Zabik et al; J Agric Food Chem 43: 993-1001 (1995)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: DDD was detected in finfish from Maryland waters at concns of 0-0.37 ug/g (1976), 0.01-0.26 ug/g (1977), 0-0.28 ug/g (1978), 0-0.11 ug/g (1979) and 0-0.49 ug/g (1980)(1). DDD was detected in perch from Patapsco River, MD at concns of 0.02-0.34 ug/g in the spring of 1976(1). The mean concns of DDD in various shellfish from New Zealand were reported as 18-768 ng/g(2). The mean concns of DDD in pike and perch caught from Lake Orsjoen, Norway in 1994 ranged from 0.26-2,960 ng/g(3). The mean concns of DDD in 8 species of fish caught from the coastal waters of Greenland ranged from 2-182 ng/g(4). The mean concns of DDD in fish from the Mahala Water reservoir, India ranged from 0.14-2.66 ug/g(5). Shellfish from Catalonia, Spain had DDD levels of 3.4-15.0 ng/g(6). DDD was detected in the skin of chinook salmon caught in 1991 from the Great Lakes at concns 3.1-29.8 ppm(7).

fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Residues in animals in different trophic levels from the Weser estuary (1976): brown shrimp (Crangon crangon), 0.7 + or - 0.2 ng/g wet tissue; in marine animal from Central Mediterranean (1976-1977): tuna (Thunnus thynnus thynus), avg 1.6 ppb fresh wt (n= 5) range 0.3-2.9 ppb fresh wt.

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: Callahan, M.A., M.W. Slimak, N.W. Gabel, et al. Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants. Volume I. EPA-440/4 79-029a. Washington, DC: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, December 1979., p. 23-6
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Clear Lake, a fresh water lake in northern California, was treated with DDD at levels of 14 ppb in 1949, and 20 ppb in 1954 and again in 1957. Deaths of numerous grebes in 1954-1955 and 1957 ... prompted examination of DDD levels in wildlife of the area. Analysis of nine fish species in the lake showed a concn of DDD in edible fish flesh ranging from 5.0 to 221 ppm, with DDD levels in visceral fat exceeding 2000 ppm in some samples.

fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: On 3 occasions, in 1949, 1954 and 1957, DDD was sprayed directly onto the lake to control gnats in Clear Lake. ... The residues persisted in the lake for over 19 years, and were recorded in 1976 in fish from the lake.

logP.References: Sangster J; LOGKOW Databank. Sangster Res. Lab., Montreal Quebec, Canada (1994)

mechanism_of_action.References: WHO; Environ Health Criteria: DDT and its Derivatives p.105 (1979)
mechanism_of_action.Value: ... Following ... dosage of (60 mg/kg, iv), all of the isomers of TDE inhibited ACTH-induced steroid production in the dog, but the inhibition reached 50% of the control only 27 min after dosing with the m,p'-isomer compared with 87 min with the o,p'-isomer and 4-18 hr with the p,p'-isomer. There was marked temporal correlation between the percentage inhibition of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-induced steroid production, the disruption of normal cellular structure of the fascicular and reticular zones of the adrenal cortex, and the severity of the damage to mitochondria in these zones caused by the three isomers.

In this study, we determined whether the DDT isomers p,p'-DDT [1,1,1,-trichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane], o,p'-DDT [1,1,1-trichloro-2(p-chlorophenyl)-2-(o-chlorophenyl)ethane], and their metabolites p,p'-DDD [1,1-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane], o,p'-DDD [1,1-dichloro-2-(p-chlorophenyl)-2-(o-chlorophenyl)ethane], p,p'-DDE [1,1,-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethylene], o,p'-DDE [1,1-dichloro-2-(p-chlorophenyl)-2-(o-chlorophenyl)ethylene], and p,p'-DDA [2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)acetic acid], could bind to and transcriptionally activate the human estrogen receptor (hER). Novel results from competitive binding assays showed that o,p'-DDD, o,p'-DDE, and p,p'-DDT, as well as the established environmental estrogen o,p'-DDT, were able to bind specifically to the hER with approximately 1000-fold weaker affinities for the hER than that of estradiol. In contrast, only o,p'-DDT, but not p,p'-DDT, bound to the rat estrogen receptor. Moreover, two yeast expression-reporter systems, constructed to test if the DDT isomers and metabolites could transcriptionally activate the hER, demonstrated that an o,p'-DDT metabolite could transactivate the hER or LexA-hER fusion protein with just a 140- to 300-fold weaker potency than that of estradiol. The DDT isomers and metabolites that bound the hER in vitro triggered estrogen receptor-mediated transcription of the lacZ reporter gene in the yeast systems. Furthermore, the DDT isomers and metabolites that transactivated the hER elicited an additive response when given together or with estradiol. The DDT isomers and metabolites that triggered transcription of the yeast expression-reporter systems also stimulated two estrogenic endpoints in estrogen-responsive MCF-7 cells: the induction of the progesterone receptor and the down-regulation of the hER. Thus, in MCF-7 cells and in yeast expression-reporter systems, certain DDT isomers and metabolites act directly as agonists and transactivate the hER at concentrations found in human tissues.

Using a combination of in vitro assays we have evaluated whether DDT metabolites can interact with the progesterone receptor pathway in yeast expressing human progesterone receptor (hPR) and in T47D human breast cancer cells which express endogenous hPR. In transactivation assays using both yeast and T47D cells, o,p'-DDT and the metabolites p,p'-DDT, o,p'-DDD, p,p'-DDD, o,p'-DDE, p,p'-DDE, p,p'-DDA, and DDOH inhibited progesterone-induced reporter gene activity in a dose-dependent manner. None of the DDT metabolites functioned as hPR agonists. Whole cell competition binding assays using T47D cells indicated that the inhibitory effects of DDT metabolites on progesterone-dependent activites may occur through both hPR-dependent and hPR-independent pathways. Our results and previous reports of DDT metabolites interacting with estrogen and androgen receptors suggests that this class of environmental chemicals may interact with numerous hormone receptor signaling pathways.

The mechanisms of action of o,p'-DDD on adrenal steroidogenesis were investigated in vitro in rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss). Acute exposures to o,p'-DDD inhibited ACTH-stimulated cortisol secretion while cell viability decreased significantly only at the highest concentration tested (200 microM o,p'-DDD). Stimulation of cortisol secretion with a cAMP analogue (dibutyryl-cAMP) was inhibited at a higher concentration than that needed to inhibit ACTH-stimulated cortisol synthesis in cells exposed to o,p'-DDD. Forskolin-stimulated cortisol secretion and cAMP production, and NaF-stimulated cAMP production were inhibited in a concentration-dependent manner by o,p'-DDD. In contrast, basal cortisol secretion was stimulated while basal cAMP production was unaffected by o,p'-DDD. Pregnenolone-stimulated cortisol secretion was enhanced by o,p'-DDD at a physiologically relevant pregnenolone concentration, while o,p'-DDD inhibited cortisol secretion when a pharmacological concentration of pregnenolone was used. /These/ results suggest that the cAMP generation step is a target in o,p'-DDD-mediated disruption of ACTH-stimulated adrenal steroidogenesis in rainbow trout but that other downstream targets such as steroidogenic enzymes responsible for cortisol synthesis might also be affected.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clarke, M. L., D. G. Harvey and D. J. Humphreys. Veterinary Toxicology. 2nd ed. London: Bailliere Tindall, 1981., p. 140
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ Doses of 20-50 mg/kg daily to dogs have been found to produce atrophy and disappearance of the deeper layers of the adrenal cortex; only the zona glomerulosa and the narrow outer part of the zona fasciculata remaining. /SRP: Effects are specific to o'-DDD, which may be contaminant of p,p'-DDD/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Nims RW et al; J Toxicol Environ Health 53 (6): 455-77 (1998)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ In this study the pharmacodynamics were characterized of rat hepatic cytochrome P450 2B (CYP2B) induction by the pesticide DDT [1,1,1-trichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane] and its metabolites DDE [1,1-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethylene], which is bioretained, and DDD [1,1-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane], which is metabolized further and therefore less prone to bioaccumulate. DDT, DDE, and DDD were each found to be pure phenobarbital-type cytochrome P450 inducers in the male F344/NCr rat, causing induction of hepatic CYP2B and CYP3A, but not CYP1A. The ED50 values for CYP2B induction (benzyloxyresorufin O-dealkylation) by DDT, DDE, and DDD were, respectively, 103, 88, and > or = 620 ppm in diet (14 days of exposure). The efficacies (Emax values) for induction of benzyloxyresorufin O-dealkylation by DDT, DDE, and DDD were 24-, 22-, and > or = 1-fold, respectively, compared to control values. The potencies of the three congeners for CYP2B induction appeared also to be similar, with EC50 values (based on total serum DDT equivalents) of 1.5, 1.8, and > or = 0.51 uM, respectively.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: DHHS/ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for DDT, DDE, and DDD (PB/2002/100137) (September 2002). Available from, as of May 29, 2009: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxpro2.html
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ ... Degenerative adrenal changes were reported ... after dosing dogs (by capsule) with 138.5 mg/kg/day of o,p'-DDD for 10 days. Plasma levels of cortisol were decreased and a decreased response to ACTH stimulation was observed. In one animal, there was hemorrhage, invasion by lymphocytes, and necrosis of the adrenal cortex.

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Male and female CF-1 mice were maintained for up to 130 wk on diets containing 250 ppm p,p-DDE or p,p'-DDD (TDE) or 125 ppm of the two chemicals combined. Exposure to p,p'-DDE resulted in a high incidence and early appearance of liver tumors, particularly in the female mice. Liver tumors appeared in 1% of the untreated females and 100% of the treated females. Exposure to p,p'-DDD moderately incr the incidence of liver tumors in males only and markedly incr the incidence of lung tumors in both sexes. Exposure to both chemicals combined resulted in a marked incr in the incidence of liver tumors in both sexes and in the early appearance of such tumors. The storage levels of these metabolites were higher in the fat tissue than in the liver or kidneys, and the storage concn of p,p'-DDE was higher than that of p,p'-DDD following the same exposure levels.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bioassays of DDT, TDE, and p,p'-DDE for Possible Carcinogenicity (1978) Technical Rpt Series No. 131 DHEW Pub No. (NIH) 78-1386, U.S. Department of Health Education and Welfare, National Cancer Institute, Bethesda, MD 20014
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Levels of Evidence of Carcinogenicity: For p,p'-DDE: Male Rats: Negative, Female Rats: Negative; Male Mice: Positive; Female Mice: Positive. For DDT: Male Rats: Negative; Female Rats: Negative: Male Mice: Negative; Female Mice: Negative. For TDE: Male Rats: Equivocal; Female Rats: Negative; Male Mice: Negative; Female Mice: Negative.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Aziz MA et al; Egypt J Vet Sci 16 (1-2): 89-99 (1981)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Treatment of chickens for 10 days with p,p'-DDD decreased dressing weight and giblet weight; ovary, oviduct, thyroid and testis weights were increased.

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Neurotoxicity/ In vitro analyses in mouse synaptosomes and vesicles demonstrated that DDT and its metabolites inhibit the plasma membrane dopamine transporter (DAT) and the vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT2). However, exposure of mice to either DDT or DDE failed to show evidence of nigrostriatal damage or behavioral abnormalities in any of the measures examined.

/ENDOCRINE MODULATION/ Dichlorodiphenyl dichloroethane (TDE) administration to Sprague-Dawley rats produced precocious puberty with an inverse relation between age at vagina opening and dose. Minimal effective dose for inducing persistent vaginal estrus and anovulation was 0.1 mg tetrachlorodiphenyl ethane on day 2, 3, & 4 of life. Syndrome appeared earlier in life as dosage incr. Uterine histology was markedly changed (patches of stratified squamous epithelium evident) in adult rats which grew from neonates treated with high doses. ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Mortelmans K et al; Environ Mutagen 8: 1-119 (1986)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ Rhothane was tested for mutagenicity in the Salmonella/microsome using the standard protocol approved by the National Toxicology Program. Rhothane was tested at doses of 0.033, 0.10, 0.33, 1.0, 3.3, 10, 33, and 100 ug/plate in as many as 5 Salmonella typhimurium strains (TA1535, TA1537, TA97, TA98, and TA100) in the presence and absence of rat or hamster liver S-9. Rhothane was negative in these tests and the highest ineffective dose tested in any Salmonella typhimurium strain was 100 ug/plate. Total clearing of the background lawn was observed in strain TA100 at 33 ug/plate without activation.
/GENOTOXICITY/ DDD was nonmutagenic in bacterial reversion-assay systems with 5 strains (TA100, TA98, TA1535, TA1537, and TA1538) of Salmonella typhimurium and a strain (WP2 HCR) of Escherichia coli.

Geneva: World Health Organization,  International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT.  (Multivolume work). Available at: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php, p. V53 221 (1991)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ para,para'-TDE was not mutagenic to bacteria, and an unspecified isomer of TDE did not induce unscheduled DNA synthesis in primary cultures of mouse, rat or Syrian hamster hepatocytes. para,para'-TDE weakly induced chromosomal aberrations in rodent cells. In a single study, it inhibited gap-junctional intercellular communication in cultured rodent cells. In one study, it did not induce transformation in mouse embryo cells.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: LUNDHOLM CE, MATHSON K; ACTA PHARMACOL TOXICOL 52 (5): 390-4 (1983)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ p,p'-DDD inhibited the Ca(2+) binding activity of eggshell gland mucosa of hen in vitro.

/IMMUNOTOXICITY/ Effects of 1,1,1-trichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane (DDT) and its metabolites, 1,1-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethene (DDE), 1,1-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane (DDD) and 2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl) acetic acid (DDA) were comparatively evaluated on humoral and cell mediated immune (CMI) responses in rats. Rats were given a diet containing 200 ppm of the various test compounds for 6 weeks and were subsequently immunized with ovalbumin. DDT, DDE and DDD, all induced differential degrees of humoral and cellular immune suppression. There were (a) increases in albumin/globulin ratios, (b) suppression of IgM and IgG levels, and (c) attenuations in ovalbumin induced antibody responses. In CMI studies, there were marked inhibitions of (a) leucocyte and macrophage migration factors, and (b) delayed type hypersensitivity (DTH) reaction. Whereas, these effects were most marked with DDE and DDD, DDA did not elicit such immunomodulatory effects. ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: DHHS/ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for DDT, DDE, and DDD (PB/2002/100137) (September 2002). Available from, as of May 29, 2009: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxpro2.html
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /IMMUNOTOXICITY/ ... Comparative studies ... showed that adrenal cortical cytochrome P-450 from mink and otter metabolically activate and bind both p,p'-DDD and o,p'-DDD, whereas 3-MeSO(2)-DDE is not activated by these species in vitro. Both isomers induced necrosis and focal bleeding in the zona fascicularis/zona reticularis in vivo in mink. Adrenals from chickens also activated and covalently bound 3-MeSO(2)-DDE and o,p'-DDD in vitro, and both compounds were adrenotoxic in vivo.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Bevenue A et al; Pest Monit J 6: 56-64 (1972) (2) Hindin E et al; Res Rev 7: 130-56 (1964) (3) Kuntz KW; Toxic Contaminants in the Niagara River 1975-82. Burlington Ontario Technical Bulletin No 134 (1984) (4) El-Dib MA, Badawy MI; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 34: 216-27 (1985) (5) Schacht RA; Pesticides in the Illinois Waters of Lake Michigan USEPA-600/3-74-002 (1974) (6) Staples CA et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 4: 131-42 (1985) (7) Brevik EM et al; Chemosphere 33: 2189-2200 (1996)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENTS: DDD was detected in sediment from canals in Hawaii at concns of 40-220 ppm(1). DDD was detected in the Columbia Basin, WA at concns of 0.6-95 ppb(2). DDD was detected in 63% of the sediment samples from the Niagara River at Niagara-on-the-Lake at an avg concn of avg 4 ppb from 1978-1981(3). DDD was detected in sediment from the Mediterranean Sea at Port-Said, at concns of 110-400 ppb(4). In 1971, o,p'-DDD was detected in sediment from Lake Michigan, near IL, at concns of 0.02-5.47 ppb; p,p'-DDD was detected at concns of 0.01-12.6 ppb(5). DDD was detected in 652 out of 1,087 sediment samples in the US at a median concn of 0.2 ppb(6). The concn of DDD in sediment from Lake Orsjoen, Norway ranged from 0.0002-72 mg/kg, with the greatest concns observed in the top 2 cm of sediment and the lowest concns observed in the deepest (10-12 cm) sediment(7).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Peris E; Chemosphere 60: 1542-1549 (2005) (2) Wan Mt et al; J Environ Qual 34: 1186-1193 (2005)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: DDD was detected in sediments of irrigation ditches and ravines that flow into Lake Albufera of Valencia at concns of 4.6 ng/g to 113 ng/g and no detection to 0.2 ng/g, respectively. The sampling sites were located in Valencia, Spain(1). DDD was detected in farm area ditch sediments of the Lower Fraser Valley, British Columbia (2002-2003) at a mean concn of 0.27 mg/kg dry wt, a range of <0.02 to 1.10 mg/kg dry wt, and a detection occurrence of 19 out of 36 samples(2). DDD was detected in tributary streams of the Fraser River, Lower Fraser Valley, British Columbia (2002-2003) at a mean concn of 0.07 mg/kg dry wt, a range of <0.01 to 0.22 mg/kg dry wt, and a detection occurrence of 5 out of 36 samples(2).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: Callahan, M.A., M.W. Slimak, N.W. Gabel, et al. Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants. Volume I. EPA-440/4 79-029a. Washington, DC: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, December 1979., p. 23-4
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: The DDD content of undisturbed sediments from the Santa Barbara Basin off the California Coast were examined. By means of radio dating of the sediment layers it was determined that DDD began to appear in about 1955 (at 12 ppb concn) and attained 18 ppb levels by 1976.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Kumari B et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 57: 787-93 (1996) (2) Carey AE et al; Pest Monit J 12: 117-36 (1978) (3) Wiersma GB et al; Pest Monit Journal 6: 126-9 (1972) (4) Albright R et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 12: 378-84 (1974) (5) Suzuki M et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 12: 275-80 (1974) (6) Carey AE et al; Pest Monit J 14: 23-5 (1980) (7) Harris CR, Sans WW; Pest Monit J 5: 259-67 (1971)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: DDD was detected in soils from India at concns of 0.007-0.008 ug/g in 1992-1994(1). DDD was detected in 116 out of 1,487 soil samples from 37 states in the US at concns of 0.01-38.46 ppm in 1971(2). In another study, DDD was detected in soil samples from 8 US cities at avg concns of 0.02-0.41 ppm(3). DDD was detected in 4 of 46 soil samples from west Alabama at max concns less than 0.1 ppm(4). DDD was detected in agricultural soils from Kitakyushu, Japan at concns of 0.018-1.554 ppm(5). DDD was detected in agricultural soils from 5 US rice growing states at concns of 0.01-0.94 ppm (dry wt)(6). DDD was detected in soils from southwestern Ontario farms at avg concns of 0.49 ppm (1964), 0.40 ppm (1966) and 0.42 (1969)(7).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Hong Z et al; Chemosphere 60: 762-769 (2005) (2) Tao Z et al; Environ Sci Tehcnol 39: 2494-2499 (2005) (3) Wan Mt et al; J Environ Qual 34: 1186-1193 (2005)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: DDD was detected in farmland soils collected in 2003 in the area of the Guanting Reservoir near Beijing, China. DDT and other organochlorine pesticides were banned in China in 1982. The median concn of DDD (n = 30) was reported as 0.30 ng/g, with a range of no detection to 7.54 ng/g, and a standard deviation of 1.64(1). A monitoring study was conducted on agricultural soils (bulk and rhizosphere soils) at two sites in Tianjin, China: site A which had no known history of wastewater irrigation from local industry and site B, which had a 40 year history of wastewater irrigation. DDD was detected in bulk soils at a mean concn of 4.4 +/- 0.24 ng/g at site A and a mean concn of 45 ng/g at site B. In rhizosphere soils, it had mean concns of 4.6 ng/g at site A and 16 ng/g at site B(2). DDD was detected in crop soils of the Lower Fraser Valley, British Columbia (2002-2003) at a mean concn of 0.63 mg/kg dry wt, a range of <0.02 to 6.00 mg/kg dry wt, and a detection occurrence of 24 out of 36 samples(3).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Ding JW, Wu SC; Chemosphere 30: 2259-66 (1995) (2) Ding JW, Wu SC; Wat Sci Technol 35: 139-45 (1997) (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)  (4) van den Hoop M et al; Air Water Soil Pollut 110: 57-66 (1999)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of DDD was measured as 130,600(1) and 131,800(2) in soil column batch experiments. According to a classification scheme(3), these Koc values suggest that DDD is expected to be immobile in soil. The average log Koc of DDD in lake sediment was 4.57(4).
